Introduction

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a life-threatening systemic condition characterized by widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to the formation of microvascular thrombi and simultaneous consumption of platelets and coagulation factors.  This can result in concurrent thrombosis and severe bleeding.  DIC typically occurs secondary to an underlying condition and requires urgent intervention.

Pathogenesis



The goal of hemostasis is to maintain the integrity of a high-pressure circulatory system.  It is a coordinated process that involves the formation of a fibrin clot at the site of vascular injury, followed by clot lysis (ie, fibrinolysis) as the injured tissue undergoes repair.  If any step in this process is disrupted, abnormal bleeding or clotting can occur.



DIC (

figure 1
) occurs when widespread activation of the coagulation cascade (
figure 2
) overwhelms normal regulatory mechanisms.  This typically involves:



  • Systemic exposure to procoagulants (eg, endotoxins, trauma-induced tissue factor release), which leads to excessive thrombin generation and rapid consumption of platelets, coagulation factors, and fibrinogen to form platelet-rich, cross-linked fibrin clots.
  • Secondary fibrinolysis, in which plasminogen is converted to plasmin, which cleaves the cross-linked fibers that form the fibrin clot, generating fibrin degradation products (eg, D-dimer).  In addition to plasmin, widespread fibrinolysis also depletes other anticoagulant proteins (eg, protein C, protein S, antithrombin).


As a result, patients are prone to the following:



  • Hemorrhage:  Coagulation factor consumption outpaces production, causing coagulopathic bleeding at various sites (eg, mucosal surfaces, venipuncture sites).  In addition, fibrin degradation products can interfere with platelet aggregation and fibrin clot formation, exacerbating coagulopathic bleeding.
  • Organ injury:  Thrombi can obstruct blood flow through the microvasculature, leading to tissue ischemia in vital organs (eg, kidneys, lungs, brain, liver).
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA):  Thrombi can also shear red blood cells as they traverse the fibrin meshwork, resulting in hemolysis.

Causes and risk factors



DIC develops secondary to an underlying condition.  The most common underlying conditions (ie, risk factors) include:



  • Sepsis:  the most common cause of DIC; associated with gram-negative pathogens that release bacterial endotoxin.
  • Traumatic tissue injury (eg, severe crush injuries or burns):  When damaged, vascular endothelium exposes tissue factor, a procoagulant protein that triggers the coagulation cascade.  The risk for DIC is particularly increased if there is CNS involvement.
  • Obstetric complications (eg, postpartum hemorrhage, placental abruption (
    figure 3
    )):  can lead to massive hemorrhage with tissue factor release (
    figure 4
    ).  Introduction of amniotic fluid into the maternal circulation can also induce DIC.
  • Malignancy:  DIC is the most common coagulopathy in patients with malignancy, including acute promyelocytic leukemia and mucin-producing solid tumors (eg, pancreatic, gastric, ovarian, breast).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of DIC is variable and may include thrombotic and/or hemorrhagic symptoms, depending on the balance of clot formation and clot lysis in each patient.  These include:



  • Thrombotic symptoms:  Patients may have signs of end organ damage from vascular occlusion and microinfarctions (eg, confusion due to cerebral ischemia, hemoptysis due to pulmonary ischemia).  Vascular occlusion can also result in purpura fulminans (
    image 1
    ).
  • Hemorrhagic symptoms:  typically involve venipuncture or surgical sites.  Patients may also have signs of mucocutaneous, gastrointestinal, uterine, or pulmonary hemorrhage.  Skin examination may reveal ecchymosis and petechiae.


In addition, the patient may have symptoms of the underlying condition that lead to DIC (eg, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension suggestive of sepsis; vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness suggestive of placental abruption).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of DIC involves history and physical examination findings (eg, thrombotic/hemorrhagic symptoms with an underlying condition associated with DIC) with consistent laboratory findings:

Consumptive coagulopathy



  • Thrombocytopenia:  due to platelet consumption.  Peripheral smear may show large, immature platelets, suggesting that the thrombocytopenia is due to increased consumption, rather than decreased production.
  • Prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT):  occurs because coagulation factor consumption outpaces production.
  • Low fibrinogen level:  due to rapid consumption.

Fibrinolysis



  • Elevated D-dimer level
  • Decreased protein C, protein S, and antithrombin levels

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia



  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase, bilirubin levels, and reticulocyte count
  • Decreased hemoglobin levels
  • Schistocytes (ie, fragmented erythrocytes) (
    image 2
    ) on peripheral blood smear:  due to shearing of circulating erythrocytes through fibrin strands in the microvasculature.

Differential diagnosis



  • Conditions associated with hemorrhage and coagulopathy:  Hepatic dysfunction is the most common.  Because thrombopoietin and most coagulation factors are synthesized in the liver, hepatic dysfunction causes thrombocytopenia, and PT and aPTT prolongation.  Factor VIII is not synthesized in the liver and is therefore normal in liver dysfunction.  In addition, patients with liver dysfunction have normal fibrinogen levels (in contrast to DIC).
  • Conditions associated with thrombosis:  Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by thromboembolism.  Thrombocytopenia can also occur.  aPTT is typically prolonged (because the antiphospholipid antibody interferes with the test), but PT is typically normal.
  • Conditions associated with MAHA with thrombocytopenia:
    • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura: caused by reduced activity of von Willebrand factorâ€“cleaving protein (ADAMTS13), leading to the accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers that trap platelets and generate platelet-rich thrombi in the microvasculature.  Patients usually develop thrombocytopenia, MAHA, fever, confusion, and organ damage (eg, acute renal failure), which can present similarly to DIC.  However, the coagulation cascade is unaffected; therefore, PT, aPTT, and fibrinogen levels are normal.
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS):  Often seen in children after diarrhea, HUS involves microangiopathy and thrombocytopenia but not widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, as seen in DIC.

Management



The management of DIC involves treating the underlying condition and replacing blood products.

Treat the underlying condition



This is the primary principle in management of DIC because it eliminates the original cause for ongoing coagulation and thrombosis.  This may include:



  • Antibiotics for sepsis
  • Surgical management of trauma
  • Obstetric intervention for placental abruption
  • Chemotherapy for malignancy

Blood product replacement



The status of the coagulopathy should be regularly monitored with serial laboratory testing (eg, platelet counts, PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, D-dimer) to evaluate for continued detioration or improvement of DIC.  If the patient continues to have coaguloapthy, treatment includes:



  • Platelets
  • Fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors
  • Cryoprecipitate to replenish fibrinogen


Low doses of heparin may be considered in patients with thrombotic manifestations of DIC but are contraindicated in cases of significant hemorrhage.  Antifibrinolytics are generally contraindicated due to the risk for thrombotic complications.  However, they may be considered in rare cases with severe hemorrhage.

Chronic DIC



Patients with solid tumors may have chronic DIC (

), a compensated, indolent form of DIC in which intermittent secretion of tissue factor into the circulation triggers consumption of coagulation factors.  However, in chronic DIC, coagulation factor consumption does not outpace production.  Patients with chronic DIC are able to compensate for intermittent coagulation and fibrinolysis via increased production of coagulation factors, platelets, and fibrinogen.  Therefore, they are often asymptomatic.  If symptomatic, patients with chronic DIC are more likely to have thrombosis (eg, deep vein thrombosis) than bleeding.  Laboratory evaluation may show signs of thrombin generation and fibrinolysis (ie, increased D-dimer).  Platelet counts and coagulation times are typically normal.

Prognosis



The prognosis of DIC depends primarily on the underlying cause (eg, severity, treatment options) and the degree of coagulopathy.  Acute DIC, especially in the context of sepsis or trauma, has a high mortality rate (~50%).  Chronic DIC, often seen with malignancy, has a more favorable prognosis but may result in recurrent thromboembolic events.  Upon resolution of the underlying condition, patients with DIC tend to improve within a few days because coagulation factors and platelets are produced and fibrin degradation products are cleared.

Summary



Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (
